title: India as a Union of States
description: India, also referred to as Bharat, is a Union of States. The territories of India are defined in the First Schedule.

title: Admission or Establishment of New States
description: Parliament has the authority to admit new states into the Union of India or establish new states.

title: Formation of New States and Alteration of Areas, Boundaries, or Names of Existing States
description: Parliament can create new states, alter the areas, boundaries, or names of existing states, but must first consult the legislature of the affected state.

title: Laws Made Under Articles 2 and 3
description: Laws made under Articles 2 and 3 can also amend the First and Fourth Schedules of the Constitution without being considered a constitutional amendment.

title: Citizenship at the Commencement of the Constitution
description: Anyone born or living in India at the time the Constitution began is a citizen of India.

title: Rights of Citizenship of Certain Persons Who Have Migrated to India from Pakistan
description: People who migrated from Pakistan to India before the Constitution started are considered Indian citizens.

title: Rights of Citizenship of Certain Migrants to Pakistan
description: People who moved to Pakistan but later returned to India with permission can become citizens.

title: Rights of Citizenship of Certain Persons of Indian Origin Residing Outside India
description: People of Indian origin living abroad can be Indian citizens if registered by Indian officials.

title: Persons Voluntarily Acquiring Citizenship of a Foreign State Not to Be Citizens
description: If someone voluntarily becomes a citizen of another country, they lose their Indian citizenship.

title: Continuance of the Rights of Citizenship
description: Indian citizens continue to be citizens unless a law says otherwise.

title: Parliament to Regulate the Right of Citizenship by Law
description: Parliament has the power to make laws about who can be a citizen.

title: Definition of the State
description: The term 'State' includes the government and all its branches at national and state levels.

title: Laws Inconsistent with or in Derogation of the Fundamental Rights
description: Any laws that contradict the Fundamental Rights in the Constitution are invalid.

title: Equality Before Law
description: Everyone in India is equal before the law.

title: Prohibition of Discrimination on Grounds of Religion, Race, Caste, Sex, or Place of Birth
description: The state cannot discriminate against anyone based on religion, race, caste, sex, or place of birth.

title: Equality of Opportunity in Matters of Public Employment
description: Everyone has equal opportunity in public employment.

title: Abolition of Untouchability
description: Untouchability is abolished, and practicing it is illegal.

title: Abolition of Titles
description: No titles (like 'Sir' or 'Lord') are allowed except for military or academic honors.

title: Protection of Certain Rights Regarding Freedom of Speech, etc.
description: Citizens have the right to freedom of speech, assembly, association, movement, residence, and profession.

title: Protection in Respect of Conviction for Offences
description: No one can be punished under a law that wasn't in force when the act was committed, tried for the same offense twice, or forced to testify against themselves.

title: Protection of Life and Personal Liberty
description: Every person has the right to life and personal liberty, except as per the law.

title: Right to Education
description: The state must provide free and compulsory education to children aged 6-14.

title: Protection Against Arrest and Detention in Certain Cases
description: Anyone arrested must be informed of the reason and presented before a magistrate within 24 hours.

title: Prohibition of Traffic in Human Beings and Forced Labour
description: Human trafficking and forced labor are illegal.

title: Prohibition of Employment of Children in Factories, etc.
description: Children under 14 cannot be employed in factories or dangerous jobs.

title: Freedom of Conscience and Free Profession, Practice, and Propagation of Religion
description: Everyone has the right to practice and propagate their religion, subject to public order, morality, and health.

title: Freedom to Manage Religious Affairs
description: Religious groups can manage their religious affairs, own property, and run institutions.

title: Freedom as to Payment of Taxes for Promotion of Any Particular Religion
description: No one is forced to pay taxes for promoting any religion.

title: Freedom as to Attendance at Religious Instruction or Religious Worship in Certain Educational Institutions
description: No religious instruction is allowed in state-funded educational institutions unless they are established by an endowment or trust.

title: Protection of Interests of Minorities
description: Minorities have the right to preserve their culture, language, and script, and cannot be denied admission to state-funded institutions based on religion, race, or language.

title: Right of Minorities to Establish and Administer Educational Institutions
description: Minorities can establish and manage their educational institutions and are protected against discrimination by the state.

title: (Repealed)
description: This article was repealed.

title: Saving of Laws Providing for Acquisition of Estates, etc.
description: Laws related to the acquisition of estates by the state are protected from being challenged under certain fundamental rights.

title: Validation of Certain Acts and Regulations
description: Certain laws, listed in the Ninth Schedule, are protected from being challenged under fundamental rights.

title: Saving of Laws Giving Effect to Certain Directive Principles
description: Laws aimed at implementing certain Directive Principles cannot be challenged on the grounds that they violate fundamental rights.

title: (Repealed)
description: This article was repealed.

title: Remedies for Enforcement of Rights Conferred by this Part
description: Citizens can approach the Supreme Court to enforce their fundamental rights.

title: (Repealed)
description: This article was repealed.

title: Power of Parliament to Modify the Rights Conferred by this Part in Their Application to Forces, etc.
description: Parliament can modify the application of fundamental rights for armed forces and related services to maintain discipline.

title: Restriction on Rights Conferred by this Part While Martial Law is in Force in any Area
description: Parliament can restrict fundamental rights during martial law to maintain order.

title: Legislation to Give Effect to the Provisions of this Part
description: Parliament has the power to make laws to enforce the provisions of Part III (Fundamental Rights).

title: Definition
description: In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires, ‘the State’ has the same meaning as in Part III.

title: Application of the Principles Contained in this Part
description: The principles in this Part are fundamental in the governance of the country and it is the duty of the State to apply them in making laws.

title: State to Secure a Social Order for the Promotion of Welfare of the People
description: The State shall strive to promote the welfare of the people by securing and protecting a social order in which justice, social, economic, and political, shall inform all the institutions of the national life.

title: Certain Principles of Policy to be Followed by the State
description: The State shall, in particular, direct its policy towards securing: (a) adequate means of livelihood for all citizens; (b) ownership and control of material resources to subserve the common good; (c) operation of the economic system does not result in the concentration of wealth; (d) equal pay for equal work for both men and women; (e) health and strength of workers, men, and women, and the tender age of children are not abused; and (f) opportunities for healthy development of children.

title: Equal Justice and Free Legal Aid
description: The State shall secure that the operation of the legal system promotes justice, on a basis of equal opportunity, and shall, in particular, provide free legal aid.

title: Organisation of Village Panchayats
description: The State shall take steps to organise village panchayats and endow them with such powers and authority as may be necessary to enable them to function as units of self-government.

title: Right to Work, to Education and to Public Assistance in Certain Cases
description: The State shall provide support for work, education, and public assistance in cases of unemployment, old age, sickness, and disability within its economic capacity.

title: Provision for Just and Humane Conditions of Work and Maternity Relief
description: The State shall make provisions for securing just and humane conditions of work and maternity relief.

title: Living Wage, etc., for Workers
description: The State shall endeavor to secure, by suitable legislation or economic organization, a living wage and decent standard of life for all workers.

title: Participation of Workers in Management of Industries
description: The State shall take steps to ensure the participation of workers in the management of industries.

title: Uniform Civil Code for the Citizens
description: The State shall endeavor to secure a Uniform Civil Code for all citizens across India.

title: Provision for Early Childhood Care and Education to Children Below the Age of Six Years
description: The State shall provide early childhood care and education for all children below the age of six years.

title: Promotion of Educational and Economic Interests of Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, and Other Weaker Sections
description: The State shall promote the educational and economic interests of the Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, and other weaker sections of society.

title: Duty of the State to Raise the Level of Nutrition and the Standard of Living and to Improve Public Health
description: The State shall raise the level of nutrition, the standard of living, and improve public health.

title: Organisation of Agriculture and Animal Husbandry
description: The State shall organize agriculture and animal husbandry on modern and scientific lines.

title: Protection and Improvement of Environment and Safeguarding of Forests and Wildlife
description: The State shall protect and improve the environment and safeguard forests and wildlife.

title: Protection of Monuments and Places and Objects of National Importance
description: The State shall protect every monument or place or object of artistic or historic interest that is of national importance.

title: Separation of Judiciary from Executive
description: The State shall take steps to separate the judiciary from the executive in the public services of the State.

title: Promotion of International Peace and Security
description: The State shall promote international peace and security, maintain just and honorable relations between nations, foster respect for international law, and encourage settlement of international disputes by arbitration.

title: Fundamental Duties
description: It shall be the duty of every citizen of India: (a) to abide by the Constitution and respect its ideals and institutions, the National Flag and the National Anthem; (b) to cherish and follow the noble ideals which inspired our national struggle for freedom; (c) to uphold and protect the sovereignty, unity, and integrity of India; (d) to defend the country and render national service when called upon to do so; (e) to promote harmony and the spirit of common brotherhood amongst all the people of India; (f) to value and preserve the rich heritage of our composite culture; (g) to protect and improve the natural environment; (h) to develop scientific temper, humanism, and the spirit of inquiry and reform; (i) to safeguard public property and to abjure violence; (j) to strive towards excellence in all spheres of individual and collective activity; (k) to provide opportunities for education to children or ward.

title: The President of India
description: There shall be a President of India.

title: Executive Power of the Union
description: The executive power of the Union shall be vested in the President and exercised by him either directly or through officers subordinate to him in accordance with the Constitution.

clauses.description: The executive power of the Union shall be vested in the President and shall be exercised by him either directly or through officers subordinate to him in accordance with this Constitution.

Without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing provision, the supreme command of the Defence Forces of the Union shall be vested in the President and the exercise thereof shall be regulated by law.

Nothing in this article shall— (a) be deemed to transfer to the President any functions conferred by any existing law on the Government of any State or other authority; or (b) prevent Parliament from conferring by law functions on authorities other than the President.

title: Election of President
description: The President shall be elected by the members of an electoral college consisting of the elected members of both Houses of Parliament and the Legislative Assemblies of States.

title: Manner of Election of President
description: The election of the President shall be in accordance with the system of proportional representation by means of the single transferable vote, and the voting at such election shall be by secret ballot.

title: Term of Office of President
description: The President shall hold office for a term of five years from the date on which he enters upon his office.

clauses.description: The President shall hold office for a term of five years from the date on which he enters upon his office.
Notwithstanding the expiration of his term, the President shall continue to hold office until his successor enters upon his office.
The President may, by writing under his hand addressed to the Vice President, resign his office.
A President may be removed from office by impeachment for violation of the Constitution.
The procedure for the impeachment of the President shall be as provided in Article 61.

title: Eligibility for Re-election
description: A person who holds, or who has held, office as President shall be eligible for re-election to that office.

title: Qualifications for Election as President
description: No person shall be eligible for election as President unless he is a citizen of India, has completed 35 years of age, and is qualified for election as a member of the House of the People.

title: Conditions of President's Office
description: The President shall not be a member of either House of Parliament or of a House of the Legislature of any State, and shall not hold any other office of profit.

clauses.description: The President shall not be a member of either House of Parliament or of a House of the Legislature of any State, and if a member of either House of Parliament or of a House of the Legislature of any State be elected President, he shall be deemed to have vacated his seat in that House on the date on which he enters upon his office as President.
The President shall not hold any other office of profit.

The President shall be entitled without payment of rent to the use of his official residences and shall be also entitled to such emoluments, allowances, and privileges as may be determined by Parliament by law.
The emoluments and allowances of the President shall not be diminished during his term of office.

title: Oath or Affirmation by the President
description: The President shall take an oath or affirmation before entering upon his office, swearing to faithfully execute his duties and to preserve, protect, and defend the Constitution and the law.

title: Procedure for Impeachment of the President
description: The President can be impeached for the violation of the Constitution.

clauses.description: When a President is to be impeached, the charge shall be preferred by either House of Parliament.

No charge shall be preferred unless it is signed by at least one-fourth of the total number of members of the House and is passed by a majority of not less than two-thirds of the total membership of the House.
When a charge has been preferred by either House, the other House shall investigate the charge or cause the charge to be investigated.
If, as a result of the investigation, a two-thirds majority of that House supports the charge, the President shall be removed from office.

title: Time of Holding Election to Fill Vacancy in the Office of President and the Term of Office of Person Elected to Fill Casual Vacancy
description: An election to fill a vacancy in the office of President must be held within six months of the occurrence of the vacancy, and the person elected shall hold office for the full term of five years.

title: The Vice President of India
description: There shall be a Vice President of India.

title: The Vice President to be Ex Officio Chairman of the Council of States
description: The Vice President shall be ex officio Chairman of the Council of States and shall not hold any other office of profit.

title: The Vice President to Act as President or to Discharge His Functions During Casual Vacancies in the Office, or During the Absence, of President
description: In the event of a vacancy in the office of the President, the Vice President shall act as President until a new President is elected. If the President is temporarily unable to perform his duties, the Vice President shall discharge those functions.

clauses.description: The Vice President shall act as President in the event of a vacancy in the office of President by reason of his death, resignation, or removal, or otherwise.
When the President is unable to discharge his functions due to absence, illness, or any other cause, the Vice President shall discharge his functions until the President resumes his duties.
The Vice President, when discharging the duties of the President, shall have all the powers and immunities of the President.

title: Election of Vice President
description: The Vice President shall be elected by the members of an electoral college consisting of the members of both Houses of Parliament.

title: Term of Office of Vice President
description: The Vice President shall hold office for a term of five years. He may resign by writing to the President or may be removed from office by a resolution of the Council of States passed by a majority and agreed to by the House of the People.

title: Time of Holding Election to Fill Vacancy in the Office of Vice President and the Term of Office of Person Elected to Fill Casual Vacancy
description: An election to fill a vacancy in the office of Vice President must be held as soon as possible, and the person elected shall hold office for the full term of five years.

title: Oath or Affirmation by the Vice President
description: The Vice President shall take an oath or affirmation before entering upon his office, swearing to faithfully discharge his duties.

title: Discharge of President's Functions in Other Contingencies
description: Parliament may make provisions for discharging the President's functions in any contingency not provided for in the Constitution.

title: Matters Relating to, or Connected with, the Election of a President or Vice President
description: All doubts and disputes relating to the election of the President or Vice President shall be inquired into and decided by the Supreme Court.

clauses.description: All doubts and disputes arising out of or in connection with the election of a President or Vice President shall be inquired into and decided by the Supreme Court.

If the election of a person as President or Vice President is declared void by the Supreme Court, acts done by him in the office of President or Vice President before the date of such declaration shall not be invalidated.
Subject to the provisions of this Constitution, Parliament may by law regulate any matter relating to or connected with the election of a President or Vice President.
The election of a person as President or Vice President shall not be challenged on the ground of any vacancy in the electoral college electing him.

title: Power of President to Grant Pardons, etc., and to Suspend, Remit, or Commute Sentences in Certain Cases
description: The President shall have the power to grant pardons, reprieves, respites, or remissions of punishment, or to suspend, remit, or commute the sentence of any person convicted of any offense.

clauses.description: The President shall have the power to grant pardons, reprieves, respites, or remissions of punishment or to suspend, remit, or commute the sentence of any person convicted of any offense.

The President's power under this article extends to cases where the punishment or sentence is by a court-martial, for offenses against laws relating to matters within the executive power of the Union, or where the sentence is of death.

title: Extent of Executive Power of the Union
description: The executive power of the Union shall extend to matters with respect to which Parliament has power to make laws, and to the exercise of such rights, authority, and jurisdiction as are exercisable by the Government of India by virtue of any treaty or agreement.

clauses.description: The executive power of the Union shall extend to matters with respect to which Parliament has power to make laws.

The executive power referred to in clause (1) shall not, save as expressly provided in this Constitution or in any law made by Parliament, extend in any State to matters with respect to which the Legislature of the State has also power to make laws.

title: Council of Ministers to Aid and Advise President
description: There shall be a Council of Ministers with the Prime Minister at the head to aid and advise the President.

clauses.description: There shall be a Council of Ministers with the Prime Minister at the head to aid and advise the President who shall, in the exercise of his functions, act in accordance with such advice.
The question whether any, and if so what, advice was tendered by Ministers to the President shall not be inquired into in any court.

title: Other Provisions as to Ministers
description: The Prime Minister shall be appointed by the President and the other Ministers shall be appointed by the President on the advice of the Prime Minister.

clauses.description: The Prime Minister shall be appointed by the President and the other Ministers shall be appointed by the President on the advice of the Prime Minister.
The Ministers shall hold office during the pleasure of the President.
The Council of Ministers shall be collectively responsible to the House of the People.
Before a Minister enters upon his office, the President shall administer to him the oaths of office and of secrecy.
A Minister who for any period of six consecutive months is not a member of either House of Parliament shall at the expiration of that period cease to be a Minister.
The salaries and allowances of Ministers shall be such as Parliament may from time to time by law determine and, until Parliament so determines, shall be as specified in the Second Schedule.

title: Attorney-General for India
description: The President shall appoint a person who is qualified to be appointed a Judge of the Supreme Court to be Attorney-General for India.

clauses.description: The President shall appoint a person who is qualified to be appointed a Judge of the Supreme Court to be Attorney-General for India.

It shall be the duty of the Attorney-General to give advice to the Government of India upon such legal matters, and to perform such other duties of a legal character, as may from time to time be referred or assigned to him by the President.
In the performance of his duties, the Attorney-General shall have the right of audience in all courts in the territory of India.
The Attorney-General shall hold office during the pleasure of the President and shall receive such remuneration as the President may determine.

title: Conduct of Business of the Government of India
description: All executive action of the Government of India shall be expressed to be taken in the name of the President.

clauses.description: All executive action of the Government of India shall be expressed to be taken in the name of the President.
Orders and other instruments made and executed in the name of the President shall be authenticated as specified by rules to be made by the President.

The validity of an order or instrument which is authenticated in accordance with rules shall not be called into question on the ground that it is not an order or instrument made or executed by the President.

title: Duties of Prime Minister as Respecting the Furnishing of Information to the President, etc.
description: It shall be the duty of the Prime Minister to communicate to the President all decisions of the Council of Ministers relating to the administration of the Union and proposals for legislation.

clauses.description: It shall be the duty of the Prime Minister to communicate to the President all decisions of the Council of Ministers relating to the administration of the Union and proposals for legislation.
The Prime Minister shall furnish such information relating to the administration of the affairs of the Union and proposals for legislation as the President may call for.

If the President so requires, the Prime Minister shall submit for the consideration of the Council of Ministers any matter on which a decision has been taken by a Minister but which has not been considered by the Council.

title: Constitution of Parliament
description: There shall be a Parliament for the Union which shall consist of the President and two Houses, to be known respectively as the Council of States and the House of the People.

title: Composition of the Council of States
description: The Council of States shall consist of not more than 250 members, of whom 12 are nominated by the President and the rest are elected by the elected members of the Legislative Assemblies of the States and Union territories.

clauses.description: The Council of States shall consist of— (a) twelve members to be nominated by the President; and (b) not more than two hundred and thirty-eight representatives of the States and of the Union territories.
The twelve members to be nominated by the President shall consist of persons having special knowledge or practical experience in literature, science, art, and social service.

The allocation of seats in the Council of States to be filled by representatives of the States and of the Union territories shall be in accordance with the provisions in that behalf contained in the Fourth Schedule.

The representatives of each State in the Council of States shall be elected by the elected members of the Legislative Assembly of the State in accordance with the system of proportional representation by means of the single transferable vote.
The representatives of the Union territories in the Council of States shall be chosen in such manner as Parliament may by law prescribe.

title: Composition of the House of the People
description: The House of the People shall consist of not more than 550 members, of whom not more than 20 members represent Union territories and 530 members represent the States.

title: Readjustment after Each Census
description: Upon the completion of each census, the allocation of seats in the House of the People and the division of each State into territorial constituencies shall be readjusted by such authority and in such manner as Parliament may by law determine.

title: Duration of Houses of Parliament
description: The Council of States shall be a permanent body and shall not be subject to dissolution. The House of the People, unless sooner dissolved, shall continue for five years from the date appointed for its first meeting.

title: Qualification for Membership of Parliament
description: A person shall not be qualified to be chosen to fill a seat in Parliament unless he is a citizen of India, and makes and subscribes before a person authorized in that behalf by the Election Commission an oath or affirmation according to the form set out for the purpose in the Third Schedule.

title: Sessions of Parliament, Prorogation, and Dissolution
description: The President shall from time to time summon each House of Parliament to meet at such time and place as he thinks fit, and in respect of each session, prorogue the House and dissolve the House of the People.

title: Right of President to Address and Send Messages to Houses
description: The President may address either House of Parliament or both Houses assembled together, and may for that purpose require the attendance of members. The President may also send messages to either House, whether with respect to a Bill then pending in Parliament or otherwise, and a House to which any message is so sent shall with all convenient dispatch consider any matter required by the message to be taken into consideration.

title: Special Address by the President
description: At the commencement of the first session after each general election to the House of the People and at the commencement of the first session of each year, the President shall address both Houses of Parliament assembled together and inform Parliament of the causes of its summons.

title: Rights of Ministers and Attorney-General as Respects Houses
description: Every Minister and the Attorney-General of India shall have the right to speak in and otherwise to take part in the proceedings of, either House, any joint sitting of the Houses, and any committee of Parliament of which he may be named a member, but shall not by virtue of this article be entitled to vote.

title: The Chairman and Deputy Chairman of the Council of States
description: The Vice President of India shall be ex officio Chairman of the Council of States, and the Council of States shall, as soon as may be, choose a member of the Council to be Deputy Chairman thereof.

title: Vacation and Resignation of, and Removal from, the Office of Deputy Chairman
description: A member holding office as Deputy Chairman of the Council of States may be removed from his office by a resolution of the Council passed by a majority of all the then members of the Council.

title: Power of the Deputy Chairman or Other Person to Perform the Duties of the Office of, or to Act as, Chairman
description: While the office of Chairman is vacant, or during any period when the Vice President is acting as, or discharging the functions of, President, the duties of the office shall be performed by the Deputy Chairman, or if the office of Deputy Chairman is also vacant, by such member of the Council of States as the President may appoint for the purpose.

title: The Chairman or the Deputy Chairman Not to Preside While a Resolution for His Removal from Office is under Consideration
description: The Chairman or Deputy Chairman shall not preside over a meeting of the Council when a resolution for his removal from office is under consideration.

title: The Speaker and Deputy Speaker of the House of the People
description: The House of the People shall, as soon as may be, choose two members of the House to be respectively Speaker and Deputy Speaker thereof.

title: Vacation and Resignation of, and Removal from, the Offices of Speaker and Deputy Speaker
description: A member holding office as Speaker or Deputy Speaker of the House of the People may be removed from his office by a resolution of the House passed by a majority of all the then members of the House.

title: Power of the Deputy Speaker or Other Person to Perform the Duties of the Office of, or to Act as, Speaker
description: While the office of Speaker is vacant, the duties of the office shall be performed by the Deputy Speaker, or if the office of Deputy Speaker is also vacant, by such member of the House of the People as the President may appoint for the purpose.

title: The Speaker or the Deputy Speaker Not to Preside While a Resolution for His Removal from Office is under Consideration
description: The Speaker or Deputy Speaker shall not preside over a meeting of the House when a resolution for his removal from office is under consideration.

title: Salaries and Allowances of the Chairman and Deputy Chairman and the Speaker and Deputy Speaker
description: There shall be paid to the Chairman and the Deputy Chairman of the Council of States, and to the Speaker and the Deputy Speaker of the House of the People, such salaries and allowances as may be respectively fixed by Parliament by law and, until provision in that behalf is so made, such salaries and allowances as are specified in the Second Schedule.

title: Secretariat of Parliament
description: Each House of Parliament shall have a separate secretarial staff: Provided that nothing in this clause shall be construed as preventing the creation of posts common to both Houses of Parliament.

title: Oath or Affirmation by Members
description: Every member of either House of Parliament shall, before taking his seat, make and subscribe before the President, or some person appointed in that behalf by him, an oath or affirmation according to the form set out for the purpose in the Third Schedule.

title: Voting in Houses, Power of Houses to Act Notwithstanding Vacancies, and Quorum
description: All questions at any sitting of either House or joint sitting of the Houses shall be determined by a majority of votes of the members present and voting, other than the Speaker or person acting as Chairman or Speaker, who shall not vote in the first instance, but shall have and exercise a casting vote in the case of an equality of votes.

title: Vacation of Seats
description: A member of either House of Parliament shall vacate his seat if he is disqualified under any law made by Parliament or if he is convicted of certain offenses.

title: Disqualification of Members
description: A person shall be disqualified from being a member of either House of Parliament if they hold an office of profit under the Government of India or if they are found guilty of certain offenses.

title: Decision on Questions as to Disqualification of Members
description: The decision on questions related to the disqualification of members of Parliament shall be made by the President of India based on the advice of the Election Commission.

title: Penalties for Sitting or Voting Before Taking Oath
description: A member of Parliament who sits or votes in either House before taking the oath or affirmation is subject to penalties.

title: Powers, Privileges, and Immunities of the Houses of Parliament and Their Members
description: The Houses of Parliament and their members have certain powers, privileges, and immunities necessary for the functioning of Parliament.

title: Salaries and Allowances of Members of Parliament
description: Salaries and allowances of members of Parliament shall be determined by Parliament, and until then, as specified in the Second Schedule.

title: Provisions Relating to the Composition of the Council of States and the House of the People
description: This article provides provisions relating to the composition of the Council of States and the House of the People.

title: Joint Sitting of Both Houses
description: In the case of a disagreement between the two Houses of Parliament on a bill, a joint sitting of both Houses may be convened.

title: Procedure at Joint Sitting
description: The procedure at a joint sitting of both Houses of Parliament is regulated by this article.

title: Money Bills
description: Money Bills can only be introduced in the House of the People, and the Council of States can only make recommendations on such bills.

title: Assent to Bills
description: The President can either give assent to a bill, withhold assent, or return the bill with a request for reconsideration.

title: Annual Financial Statement
description: The President must present an Annual Financial Statement to Parliament detailing the estimated revenues and expenditures of the Government of India.

title: Appropriation Bills
description: Appropriation Bills must be passed by Parliament to authorize the expenditure of funds from the Consolidated Fund of India.

title: Bills Reserved for the Consideration of the President
description: Certain bills are reserved by the President for consideration, and the President can either assent to them or return them with a request for reconsideration.

title: Special Provisions as to Financial Bills
description: Financial Bills have special provisions for their consideration and passage in Parliament.

title: Procedure in the House of the People
description: This article outlines the procedure for the consideration of bills and other matters in the House of the People.

title: Provisions Relating to the Speaker and Deputy Speaker
description: This article provides provisions relating to the Speaker and Deputy Speaker of the House of the People.

title: Rules of Procedure in the Houses of Parliament
description: Each House of Parliament shall make its own rules of procedure, subject to the provisions of the Constitution.

title: Powers and Privileges of the Houses of Parliament and Their Members
description: The powers and privileges of the Houses of Parliament and their members are outlined in this article.

title: Language to be Used in the Houses of Parliament
description: The language used in the Houses of Parliament and their proceedings is specified in this article.

title: Restriction on Discussion in Parliament
description: This article places restrictions on the discussion of certain matters in Parliament.

title: Validity of Proceedings of Parliament
description: The validity of proceedings in Parliament shall not be questioned on the grounds of any procedural irregularities.

title: Power of the President to Issue Ordinances
description: The President has the power to issue ordinances during the recess of Parliament, which must be laid before Parliament.

title: Constitution of Supreme Court
description: The Supreme Court of India is constituted and its composition is provided for under this article.

title: Salaries and Allowances of Judges
description: The salaries and allowances of judges of the Supreme Court are determined by Parliament.

title: Acting Chief Justice
description: The President can appoint an acting Chief Justice of the Supreme Court when the office is vacant.

title: Appointment of Additional Judges
description: The President can appoint additional judges to the Supreme Court when necessary.

title: Attendance of Retired Judges
description: Retired judges of the Supreme Court can be invited to sit and act as judges in the Supreme Court.

title: Supreme Court to be a Court of Record
